content.description:
Climb up a short section of 3rd class blocks to a small ledge. The route begins by stemming between two cracks using the crack on the left for gear. Strenuous thin stemming and small holds lead to a couple bolts which are passed by leibacking your way up the left crack to a good stance. Good gear protects the rest of the route which is a slightly overhanging finger crack requireing delicate stemming and powerful moves to the top.

There is an easier variation called 115 (one fifteen) to the left. For this variation, start the route in the same spot. After climbing past the two bolts, traverse into the right hand crack and follow it up overhanging tight hands to the top.
content.location: This route is located just to the right of Cruxus.

content.description: Start off by making big moves with small feet until you get to a jug. Clip a bolt and move up through an opening crack and follow it to an awkward belly flop ledge. Stand on the ledge and clip another bolt before moving out left onto the steep face for a short section of jug hauling before topping out. Traverse left across the slab by top to the anchors of High C.
content.location: The knife blade thin crack Right of HighC.

content.description: Start up some slopy edges on the arete until you can work your way out left using some small pockets in a wandering fracture.  Move back onto the arete and battle your way up using high steps and one hand slapping the arete while you desperately try to stay on the wall. A thank god hold gives you a moment of pause, but save some juice for the very top.
content.location: Just to the right of Sloppy Lovin' and left of David on the very prominant arete.

content.description: Follow a thin finger crack to a small bulge/roof. Get some gear in and claw your way over the top. Make a short traverse up and left around a corner to the anchors.
content.location: Splitter finger crack just left of smooth criminal and right of Mushin.

content.description:
A strenuous route with some good rests thrown in. This is one of those routes where the crux is a distinct section of the route and not just a move or two. Very sequential crimps, liebacks, pinches, high steps, one hellatious (word?) sloaper and even an off hands crack are what's involved in getting up this hidden gem of a route.

All bolts were replaced by ASCA on 4-22-17.
content.protection: 5 bolts. A few pieces of gear to 2".
content.location: Just to the right of David and left of Goofy. Starts up a shallow corner on a flat face. It is very high to the first bolt and requires some 5.11 climbing to get there. Caution should be used.

content.protection: Three bolts and a couple cams from .4” to 1”. Medium nuts useful in a couple spots.
content.location:
Just left of Sloppy lovin’ and right of use of force.

This route is incorrectly labeled route 18 in the “ Locals guide to rock climbs of Northeast California by Paul Bernard. Route 18 (sloppy lovin’) is a corner finger crack just to the left of smooth criminal in a dihedral.

content.description:
Excellent route on the far right side of the crag.

The crux comes low on thin moves past a bolt. The rest of the route is a killer hand crack that widens a bit at the very top.

You can easily access the anchors from the top of the crag, near the top of the approach gully, if you want to set up a TR.

Protection bolt replaced by ASCA on 10/07/19.
content.location: Far right side of the crag, where the approach gully meets the base.  Look for a lone bolt.

content.description: A crack with many varying levels of difficulty and requiring many different techniques to climb. Much harder than it looks from the ground. Expect to be thrown a few curve balls along the way up this beautifully aesthetic crack which has everything from fingers to fists with many pinches, crimps and slopers thrown in. Beautiful and perfect bomber gear greets you at every turn the whole way.

Some big holds at the start quickly give out to tricky moves on thin holds, liebacks and occasional tight fingers in a thin seam. This route tends to shut down all but the most well rounded climbers because the technical pumpy face moves quickly turn into a short .10a section of wide fists before then transforming into wild overhanging tight hands, heel hooks and finger cracks to the very top. Anchor with chains for rappelling on top.
content.location: Just left of the obvious roof of Camaraderie.

content.description: David starts between a steep double crack system but doesn't use the crack much. Instead you climb a series of hidden jugs that just seem to keep coming until eventually all the good holds just stop and you're forced to make a few thin and powerful moves to gain entry onto a big ledge. From this ledge you move out right heading for a perfect, steep off hands crack which will put you on top of the formation. Anchor with rappel rings on top.
content.protection: Bolts. Some might like a few pieces of gear for the crack near the top. A 1" piece (.75 C4) should do it.
content.location: About 15ft left of Goofy. Look for the faint spray paint mark that says "David" just to the right.

content.description: Start in a shallow corner and work your way out right onto the fractured face until you end up on the blunt arete. Work your way up the arete utilizing huge reaches and wild movement as you fight your way up this one. Recharge on the intermittent jugs as there are several cruxes which need to be negotiated before you can clip the chains.
content.protection: 8 bolts to a two bolt anchor with chains.
content.location: On the arete just left of Use of Force and right of S’mores.

content.description:
Very thin almost non existent holds and pure friction will get you past the two bolts that protect the lower section of this route. Good gear above in a tight fingers and hand crack lead to a cruxy section of thin fingers and then on to better (though flaring) cracks to the top.

Top anchor and  3rd protection bolt replaced by ASCA on 10-08

-

19
content.location: Right side of the crag, right of the obvious roof and dihedral of camaraderie.

content.description:
Just to the left of Goofy is a thin seam which requires some thought provoking moves and a lot of stamina. Start up some juggy holds, liebacks and thin finger jambs to a decent stance. Then power through an impossibly thin seam to reach a few crimps. Now milk that seam again to a decent finger lock, but save a bit of juice for the powerful thin finger section which protects with a few thin pieces all the way to the top.

There are two ways to climb this route. Climbing the route direct following the crack, or stemming left and using the crack of Goofy for both feet and hands which reduces the difficulty greatly.

This route was lead without using the crack of Goofy to the left utilizing three bolts which have since been removed.
content.protection:
Cams, .3" to 1". Nuts, few to medium.

1 bolt.
content.location: Just to the Right of Goofy in a thin seam.

content.description:
Climb up good holds into a tight dihedral, now take every opportunity to place even the most marginal gear but don't take too long looking because you're wasting your time, there isn't much. As you make your way up, the corner crack pinches it way down to a thin seam, so bring all the smallest gear you have.

A stemming mantle and more strenuous pure friction stemming will get you to the first piece of bomber gear about 30ft up. Now that the pressure is off, work your way to under the roof and save some juice for the flaring finger crack around the corner. Once established around the corner, follow the bomber cracks to the top.
content.protection: Few cams to 2" Smallest cams you got. Small offset nuts useful. Maybe a Yellow/blue offset alien would be nice.
content.location: Right side of the crag. Distinguished by a thin seam in a dihedral (with a small bush) that leads to a roof with a crack heading right out the corner to more cracks above.

content.description: Start up the broken up/ blocky crack system right of Sunny D to a big ledge. Now climb the wide fist crack on the left hand wall which has ample face holds to keep the difficulty in check.  A good route for beginning climbers.  Shares anchors with High C but requires a directional piece or two if top roping.
